moon.description: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite and the fifth-largest moon in the Solar System. It plays a crucial role in Earth's tides, climate, and even the stability of Earth's axial tilt.

mars.description: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet in the Solar System. Often called the Red Planet, its reddish color comes from iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
mars.waterPresence: Ice at the poles and possibly liquid water underground

saturn.description: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest planet in the Solar System. It is best known for its iconic ring system, made of ice, rock, and dust.
saturn.surfaceComposition: No solid surface; composed mainly of gas with a possible rocky core
saturn.rings: Made of ice, dust, and rock particles, stretching up to 282,000 km wide

earth.description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known celestial body to support life. It has a diverse climate, liquid water, and a protective atmosphere.
earth.waterPresence: 70% of Earth's surface is covered in liquid water

jupiter.description: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest planet in the Solar System. It is a gas giant primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, known for its Great Red Spot, a massive storm.
jupiter.surfaceComposition: No solid surface; composed mainly of gas with a possible metallic hydrogen core

mercury.description: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun and the smallest planet in the Solar System. It has no atmosphere to retain heat, making its temperatures highly extreme.
mercury.waterPresence: Ice detected in permanently shadowed craters at the poles

neptune.description: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It is an ice giant known for its deep blue color and the fastest winds in the solar system.
neptune.surfaceComposition: No solid surface; composed mainly of ice and gas with a possible rocky core

sun.description: The Sun is the star at the center of the Solar System. It is the primary source of energy for life on Earth, and its gravitational pull keeps all the planets in orbit.
sun.averageOrbitalSpeed: 220 km/s (around the center of the Milky Way)
sun.surfaceGravity: 274 m/s² (about 28 times Earth's gravity at the surface)
sun.orbitalPeriod: 225 million years (to orbit the center of the Milky Way)
sun.surfaceComposition: Mainly hydrogen and helium in a plasma state
sun.solarWind: Constant stream of charged particles (protons, electrons) emitted by the Sun

uranus.description: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and is known for its blue color, which is caused by methane in its atmosphere. It is an ice giant with a tilted axis, causing extreme seasonal variations.
uranus.surfaceComposition: No solid surface; composed mainly of water, ammonia, and methane ices
uranus.rings: Uranus has a faint ring system consisting of 13 known rings
uranus.notableFeature: Uranus is unique for its extreme axial tilt, rotating on its side

venus.description: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and is often called Earth's 'sister planet' due to its similar size and composition. It has a thick atmosphere that traps heat, making it the hottest planet in the Solar System.
venus.rotationPeriod: 243 Earth days (retrograde rotation, opposite direction of most planets)
venus.surfaceTemperature: 462°C (864°F), hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun
venus.surfaceComposition: Mainly volcanic plains with large volcanic structures and vast mountain ranges
venus.notableFeature: Venus has extreme surface pressure and an atmosphere thick with clouds of sulfuric acid, making it a highly inhospitable environment.
